urn:contentItem:5XR9-2RN1-JBCN-439C-00000-00Democrats wrong on big-tech solutions2019-12-13T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:39:50ZLexisNexisOPINIONDemocrats wrong on big-tech solutionsChristopher Koopman

From Elizabeth Warren to Tulsi Gabbard, the Democratic presidential candidates have come out strong for breaking up big tech. It has become a central focus of Warren's campaign, which has caused business leaders like Facebook's Mark Zuckerberg to voice concern, and the fight over big tech within the Democratic Party presidential primaries has bled into the courts.

In all of this, Andrew Yang has emerged as a reasoned voice against breaking up these companies. In a recent op-ed, he noted that "Breaking up Facebook or Apple sounds good, but it wouldn't address this issue." His alternative, however, is not a practical solution either. Instead of breaking up tech companies, Yang proposes a Department of the Attention Economy that will implement regulations that curb what he sees as "the negative effects of smartphones and social media."

Both the history and current reality of the Internet suggest that Yang's proposal has little chance of alleviating the addictive qualities or mental health effects that he says social media and big tech are having on Americans, young people in particular. It might only serve to make things worse.

We don't have to guess what a regulated internet will look like. For most of its history, in fact, the Internet was a tightly controlled platform called the ARPAnet, which served as the academic research network that preceded today's Internet. It was a platform in which norms and behavior were dictated to users by the federal government. Here is an excerpt of MIT's 1982 guide for new users of ARPAnet explained how it should be used:

"It is considered illegal to use the ARPAnet for anything which is not in direct support of government business. At the Al lab, we use the network to talk to other researchers about all kinds of things. For example, personal messages to other ARPAnet subscribers (for example, to arrange a get-together or check and say a friendly hello) are generally not considered harmful. This is one of the ways in which we adapt the network environment to our community. It is very clear that without that sort of freedom, the network could not have evolved to its current point of technical and social sophistication.

"Sending electronic mail over the ARPAnet for commercial profit or political purposes is both antisocial and illegal. By sending such messages, you can offend many people, and it is possible to get MIT in serious trouble with the government agencies which manage the ARPAnet."

You see, as a platform tightly controlled by the federal government, ARPAnet was regulated in an effort to stave off the perceived negative or "antisocial" effects of the commercial or political use of the platform. And while some are now arguing today that perhaps those same standards should be reinstated (just look at Twitter's ban of political advertising), it is hard to argue that the ARPAnet as conceived in 1982 would have changed the world in the way that the successive version of the commercial internet has.

But many, including Yang and Republican Sen. Josh Hawley, R-Missouri, argue in favor of heavily and specifically regulating social media in the name of curbing "social media addiction." And while we still have much to learn about whether or not this "addiction" is a serious problem, it ignores why people use the internet, to begin with. Yang's effort to create a federal agency focused on "curbing design features that maximize screen time" and discourage "Design features that encourage social validation" assumes that people are merely tricked and manipulated into using today's most popular Internet platforms. The data, however, suggests that it is not true at all.

Why do people seem so "addicted" to the internet? It may be passion, not addiction, driving users. A recent survey of Internet users found that approximately 80 million – 38.15% – of U.S. adults use the internet to pursue hobbies and passion projects. And out of those 80 million, nearly 35% of them say that the internet is essential to that pursuit. This means that there are just short of 30 million Americans that can only pursue their passion projects with the internet. Looking back at the limited acceptable applications of the internet of the early 80s, it is hard to explain why taking us back in time will make millions of Americans better off.

Putting a federal agency in a position to determine acceptable and unacceptable behavior on the internet should not be a thought experiment played out by presidential hopefuls. Instead, we should look at the history of the internet in order to understand more clearly what that world would really be like. And while "big tech" has become the target of frustration and focus of the Democratic primaries, taking us back 30 years will only serve to undermine the greatest platform we have today, to connect millions of Americans with their passions and help them find more meaning in their lives.

Christopher Koopman is executive director of the Center for Growth and Opportunity at Utah State University.

urn:contentItem:5WDR-B6X1-F03R-N1X9-00000-00Dems and GOP Senators Unite Versus Big Tech on Data Privacy Bills2019-06-25T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:39:49ZLexisNexisDems and GOP Senators Unite Versus Big Tech on Data Privacy BillsBernadette Tansey

Jun 25, 2019( Xconomy: http://www.xconomy.com/ Delivered by Newstex) To hear some people talk, you'd think the age of bipartisan action in Congress was a lost phenomenon of the distant past. But it's not so, at least when it comes to certain issues. And no one knows it better than the big Silicon Valley tech companies that are the recent targets of proposed bipartisan bills.Sen. Mark Warner, a Virginia Democrat, joined today with a Missouri Republican, Sen.

Josh Hawley, to introduce legislation[1] that would force companies like Facebook (NASDAQ: FB[2]) and Google (NASDAQ: GOOGL[3]) to reveal how much money they're making by scooping up troves of personal data on their users.If passed, the legislation would require companies with more than 100 million active users to detail the types of data they collect on people, and the transactions they make with other companies to reap revenue by granting those third parties access to that data.'When a big tech company says its product is free, consumers are the ones being sold. These 'free' products track everything we do so tech companies can sell our information to the highest bidder and use it to target us with creepy ads,' Hawley said in a written statement as he and Warner rolled out the Designing Accounting Safeguards to Help Broaden Oversight And Regulations on Data (DASHBOARD) Act on Monday.'Even worse, tech companies do their best to hide how much consumer data is worth and to whom it is sold. This bipartisan legislation gives consumers control of their data and will show them how much these 'free' services actually cost,' Hawley said.While Congress has yet to pass stringent data privacy laws like the European Union's General Data Protection Regulation(GDPR), US lawmakers' interest in the issue hasn't flagged since 2017, when detailed reports surfaced that revealed how Facebook had allowed outside organizations to tap into millions of user profiles.The initial alarms over that data exposure centered on its possible effect on the US presidential election in 2016, when entities controlled by Russia were accused of illegally targeting social media users with misleading campaign-related messages. But Congressional hearings have since expanded their scope to examine a broader concern—that tech companies are monetizing the data of individuals who are often unaware of the breadth of information they're surrendering.Under the DASHBOARD Act, big companies defined as 'commercial data operators'' would have to file annual reports disclosing the aggregate value of the data collected from their user populations. They'd have to help the Securities and Exchange Commission develop methods to calculate that value.In addition, the companies would be required to tell users each of the ways their data was being used, including those uses that have nothing to do with the main purpose of the app or service they signed up for. Users would gain some power to demand that companies delete some or all of the data collected about them.In a summary of the bill[4] posted on Scribd, Warner said the bill would not only benefit users, but would also assist US regulatory agencies such as the Federal Trade Commission, which protects consumers against business fraud and anti-competitive practices. Once US agencies understand the economic value of data collection, they can better enforce antitrust laws and flag unfair transactions, Warner said. Making the value more transparent could also increase competition by attracting rival companies into the market, he said.'User data is quickly becoming the single most important economic input in the digital economy,'' Warner wrote in the Scribd post.Warner and Hawley have also teamed up to introduce the Do Not Track Act, which would allow users to opt out of unnecessary data collection by tech companies, just as phone service customers can enroll in the FTC's 'Do Not Call' list to ward off telemarketing pitches.Last week, a Senate committee moved forward a related bipartisan bill sponsored by Warner and Colorado Republican Cory Gardner. That bill, the Internet of Things (IoT) Cybersecurity Improvement Act of 2019, would require IoT devices sold in the United States to incorporate a minimum level of cybersecurity safeguards to protect against data breaches and the infiltration of personal networks by hackers.Photo credit: Depositphotos Reprints[5] | Share: urn:contentItem:5X5W-H491-DXH2-61W3-00000-00Dems' Dwindling Impeachment Probe; 2020 Warning Signs; Pompeo Accuses House Dems Of Trying To Bully And Intimidate State Department Officials; Trump Looks To Find Out Whistleblower's Identity; Pompeo Blasts Deposition Demands; Photo Shows Joe Biden And Hunter Biden Golfing With Ukraine Gas Company Exec In 2014; Zuckerberg's 2020 Concern; China Unveils New Intercontinental Ballistic Missile at National Day Parade; Hong Kong Protests Heat Up On China's 70th Anniversary Of The Communist Party; U.S.- China Trade Talk Resume Next Week2019-10-01T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:39:50ZLexisNexisLOU DOBBS TONIGHT7:00 PM ESTStephen Miller, Eric Trump, Michael Pillsbury, Victor Davis HansonNEWSFinancial100101cb.229Dems' Dwindling Impeachment Probe; 2020 Warning Signs; Pompeo Accuses House Dems Of Trying To Bully And Intimidate State Department Officials; Trump Looks To Find Out Whistleblower's Identity; Pompeo Blasts Deposition Demands; Photo Shows Joe Biden And Hunter Biden Golfing With Ukraine Gas Company Exec In 2014; Zuckerberg's 2020 Concern; China Unveils New Intercontinental Ballistic Missile at National Day Parade; Hong Kong Protests Heat Up On China's 70th Anniversary Of The Communist Party; U.S.- China Trade Talk Resume Next WeekLou Dobbs, John Roberts, Ed Rollins

LOU DOBBS, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good evening, everybody. The Radical Dems' obstruction, subversion, and continuing effort to overthrow the Trump presidency is already showing significant signs of wear and weakness in their mad dash to contrive a fraudulent and rapidly disintegrating impeachment charge against the president, the Dems have created only an annoyance for the president, but for themselves.

They appear to have created what is a pit of quicksand. And that sucking sound you hear, it's the sinking of their hopes to frame President Trump and once again their lies laid bare before the voters.

Here is one of President Trump's tweets today showing this. A deep red 2016 election map with a message, try to impeach this. The presidential dare comes in the midst of yet another wave of disappointments and bad news for the lying leftists and Radical Dems.

President Trump's attorney, Rudy Giuliani says he's still debating whether he will defy congressional subpoenas. The Secretary of State, Mike Pompeo flat out rejected the Radical Dem committee chairman saying that he and the State Department will not permit Congress to bully, to intermediate, or disrespect distinguished diplomats.

And not a good day for the Radical Dems anywhere, and their increasingly obvious fictional plot to attack and take down the president.

New reports tonight, that Senators Joe Manchin and Jon Tester are in fact worried that Pelosi and Schiff have already severely damaged the party with their half-baked and implausible impeachment probe that's already spinning out of control, and it could prove very costly indeed in next year's elections.

For the latest tonight, we turn to Chief White House Correspondent, John Roberts.

JOHN ROBERTS, FOX NEWS CHIEF WHITE HOUSE CORRESPONDENT: Lou, good evening. The president's outside attorney, Rudy Giuliani hasn't decided whether to comply with a congressional subpoena for documents.

Neither has the secretary of state, but Mike Pompeo was doing his best to keep State Department officials away from Capitol Hill.

The Secretary of State fired back today against a House demand to depose five current and former State Department officials. In a letter to Foreign Affairs Committee Chairman, Eliot Engel, Mike Pompeo is saying, the demand can be understood only as an attempt to intimidate, bully, and treat improperly the distinguished professionals at the Department of State.

While Pompeo didn't exactly say no to Engle, he did draw a red line saying, the five officials subject to your letter may not attend any interview or deposition without counsel from the Executive Branch present.

President Trump continue to slam the whistleblower today again demanding to know his or her identity tweeting, why aren't we entitled to interview and learn everything about the whistleblower and also the person who gave all of the false information to him.

The relentless attacks prompted a rare response from the intelligence community inspector general in a four-page press release, Michael Atkinson revealing the whistleblower complaint wasn't hearsay. The whistleblower stated on the form that he or she possessed both first-hand and other information.

The I.G. did not say what information the whistleblower had first-hand knowledge of, but makes it clear that the central aspect of the complaint, the phone call was third-hand.

The complainant was not a direct witness to the president's July 25th 2019 telephone call with the Ukrainian president. Members of the relevant congressional committees may get a chance to meet with the whistleblower as soon as next week.

Fox News' told plans are being made for a possible secret meeting away from Capitol Hill to help protect the whistleblower's identity. Lou.

DOBBS: John, thank you very much. John Roberts from the White House.

So, what are the Radical Dems, Pelosi, Schiff, Schumer, left with? Right now, it appears not much and how should the Trump administration deal with a Congress that is obviously unyielding in its efforts, no matter how futile, how silly to overthrow President Trump?

To take that up, we have with us tonight, senior policy advisor for the president, Stephen Miller. Stephen, good to have you with us and what a week it has been?

Let's start with a backdrop for this if I may, and that is suddenly we are hearing from Schumer, from Pelosi and several others that they want to negotiate with the president and are ready to sit down and talk about USMCA, gun control, you name it, apparently.

They seem to think they suddenly have the upper hand with the president. Your reaction?

STEPHEN MILLER, WHITE HOUSE SENIOR POLICY ADVISER: Well, I do agree that senate democrats are probably terrified about the cliff they're being driven over by Pelosi and the radical election nullifying democrats in the house of representatives.

And so, I don't doubt that's the case, but let's also be clear what the even deeper fear is. The deepest fear is the deep state is terrified of being exposed, Lou.

What we have right now is a situation in which the attorney general of the United States and John Durham are going to get to the bottom of what really happened in 2016.

And we're going to find out what went on and what was done to try and sabotage this president and try to sabotage this administration. And that has the deep state and their democrat allies terrified.

DOBBS: And terrified it seems of what is a highly unusual effort at what is a bizarre plot at best. Not even the stuff of fiction, because it's so implausible.

But the idea that they would make much of the president asking a foreign leader to meet or talk with his attorney general and to accommodate the law enforcement and national security investigative needs of this country and ally of Ukraine. On what basis would that be irregular?

MILLER: Well, I have some breaking news, Lou. The president of the United States is the nation's highest-ranking law enforcement officer. It seems like some of our democrats need a civics lesson.

And just because Joe Biden may be running for president, doesn't mean he's immune from scrutiny. It doesn't mean that his family is immune from scrutiny for corrupt behavior in the Ukraine and in China.

And the reality is, is that the president of the United States is doing the American people a profound service by getting to the bottom of corruption in Ukraine. And all Americans have a right to know how our taxpayer dollars are being spent and whether former high-ranking officials engage in corrupt behavior and whether or not Ukraine or anyone in Ukraine engage in interference in 2016.

DOBBS: There is as I suggested at the outset, some concern that the president in the face of this onslaught, no matter how rickety a contraption of this so-called impeachment inquiry is, is being asked by the Dems and if you will a proffer perhaps as a bribe or just outright intimidation to take up gun control, to take up various issues, and legislation.

That they've had absolutely no interest in accommodating him previously. This is a sordid and tasteless sort of initiative don't you think on the part of the Radical Dems?

(LAUGHTER)

MILLER: Lou, the Democrats have truly no depth to which they will not sink in their craven pursuit of power. And that's what this is all about, Lou, right. It's about power. You know you've talked about these issues for so many years on your show.

You've talked about the betrayal of the American workers because of offshoring, outsourcing, and misguided trade deals. You've talked about the betrayal of American families because of open border policies and misguided foreign policies.

The president stood up in 2016 and said, enough, I'm putting a stop to the selling out, the betrayal, and even the crucifying of the American middle class in this country.

And they are going to say, we're not going to let the American people have the leadership and have the government that they want. And this president is standing in the breach and saying he's going to fight for the American worker.

DOBBS: And he has done so splendidly and strongly throughout. Yet over the Senate, there's a senate bill 386, the rights for legal immigrants' legislation that would double the size of H1B visas and in so doing most of those visas to China and to India.

And it's also without a question, sponsored by Mike Lee and signed on to by a host of otherwise -- well, generally reasonable people previously. Is the president going to veto the damn thing?

MILLER: Well, I don't think that that bill as it's currently written is going to be passing the Senate anytime soon. But the administration has made clear that our view on H1Bs is that you cannot displace or replace American workers.

And the president has taken unprecedented action in the immigration space to do exactly that, including most of recently with the public charge regulation to keep newcomers from taking advantage of our welfare system.

But I want to drill down to the heart, Lou, of what's happening in our country right now. You have people inside the executive branch permanent career government officials who do not recognize democracy. I know because I deal with some of these people every week.

DOBBS: You're talking about the deep state?

MILLER: I'm talking about the deep state, Lou.

DOBBS: Right.

MILLER: And everything we're trying to do to make working Americans have a better future is constantly blocked and sabotaged by the deep state. And we're breaking through and we are winning and we're going to keep on winning.

But what you have with this current non-scandal, non-controversy, made up phoney story from this fake whistleblower about Ukraine. What you have is somebody inside the government along with their allies trying to overthrow a democratically elected president so they can get their policies that they want to put in place.

That's what's at stake for every American. Do you believe we should be governed by a democracy or not?

DOBBS: Well, I'm quite happy with this constitutional republic and less than happy as you know with the deep state that it's not only entrenched, but expanding, and increasingly powerful.

When we look at the, for crying out loud, the complaint for the so-called whistleblower who happens to be a CIA officer. I mean think about the absurdity of what we're talking about, suddenly a CIA, I can't even imagine this.

A CIA officer on hearsay is now a whistleblower, one wonders why he doesn't have a change of command that he would want to follow as a CIA officer?

MILLER: Right. Yeah, you would think, right?

DOBBS: And why he could not see the irony of spying on the president of the United States on U.S. soil which is by the way --

MILLER: Yes, yes.

(LAUGHTER)

DOBBS: -- a charge that he is not entitled to. I mean this is idiotic.

MILLER: Yeah, overseas surveillance is the CIA's mission, yeah, not to try and conduct illicit operations on the president of the United States.

First of all, if you read the complaint, right, it's public now. There's no firsthand nothing in that complaint.

DOBBS: Well, there's firsthand.

MILLER: There's no firsthand anything in that complaint nor could there ever be because the complaint is the fevered imagination of a deep state radical.

DOBBS: By the way, I want to say where you're seeing that. Michael Atkinson, the inspector general of the intelligence community who wrote a four-page document of rationale for changing that complaint form, it is one of the most of absurd documents I have ever seen.

It is irrational and it can only be explained by raising great questions of political corruption within the inspector general's office itself in my opinion, but that's just my opinion. See we could -- go ahead you collect word here Stephen.

MILLER: One thing I find so disappointing, Lou, is that the Democratic Party used to stand for liberal values in this country. They used to question power, now you have a liberal bureaucracy and liberals in Washington, D.C. that worship intelligence community as being above reproach and worship deep state power.

And that is fundamentally anti-liberal. Republicans and Democrat actually ignited in supporting this president.

DOBBS: I can't join you in bemoaning their move away from liberalism. I think liberalism deserves to die and by the way that maybe at hand because of this --

MILLER: Now they're just socialists and Marxists, Lou. Not even liberals anymore. They're socialist and Marxists.

DOBBS: Well, I don't know what else they are, but I can tell you this, they're working against the president of the United States and this country and that's got to be stopped.

MILLER: Amen, Lou.

DOBBS: Stephen Miller, we appreciate everything that you're doing for the country. Thank you so much.

MILLER: Thank you.

DOBBS: More on Secretary Pompeo's answer to the Radical Dems on Capitol Hill. He's not pleased with their efforts to bully his state officials.

Ed Rollins, the savant himself with us tonight. We'll that up. And a photo of Joe Biden. Wow. Who knew, there's another photo and it shows his son and himself in -- well, the Hamptons playing golf, having a good time.

He does a lot of good-time photos, have you noticed that? Anyway, Eric Trump will be joining us right after the break with that and much, much more, stay with us.

DOBBS: The sell-off on Wall Street today, the Dow Jones Industrials fell 344 points, the S&P down 37, the Nasdaq down 91 points. Volume on the big board, 3.6 million shares. Some excitement in the market after a report that manufacturing had contracted at the fastest rate in the past year.

Crude oil down about a percent, just over $53 a barrel that's settlement. And gold up over a percent, silver rising nearly 2 percent.

A reminder, listen to my reports three times a day coast-to-coast on the Salem Radio Network.

A 2014 picture unraveling Joe Biden's claims that he never talked about his son's overseas business dealings. It could be. The picture shows the former vice-president whose son Hunter golfing in the Hamptons with Devon Archer whose archery you say.

Well, Archer and Biden, Hunter Biden were both on the board of Ukrainian gas company Burisma Holdings, also partners in the private equity firm, Rosemont Sineca. Oh yes, that's the one that attracted --

(LAUGHTER)

-- a half billion-dollar investment from China just weeks after Hunter had accompanied his father on a trip to Beijing and in December of 2013. Pure coincidence, I'm sure.

Well, joining us tonight the president son and Executive Vice-President of the Trump Organization, Eric Trump. Eric, good to have you here.

ERIC TRUMP Can you imagine if I took 3 cents from the Ukraine or 4 cents from China? I mean it's unbelievable. It's unbelievable.

DOBBS: I have a feeling it would be quite a different reaction on the part of the national leftist media. I'm just guessing but --

TRUMP: Slight double standard to say the least.

DOBBS: I think double standard is a nice way to say it. It is outright rank political corruption on the part of our national media.

TRUMP: You know the worst part of thing is? I mean first of all, the guy doesn't speak the language. So, he's on the board of a Ukrainian company and he doesn't speak the language.

All right, put me on the board of a company where I can't communicate with the other people in the company because I don't speak the language.

DOBBS: Without a third person to interpret.

TRUMP: He had no knowledge of the industry. He knew nothing about the industry at hand and he's being paid $50,000 for what? I mean for not knowing the language and not having any relevant experience within the -- it's insane. It's an absolutely insane.

DOBBS: Again, it fails the implausibility test and it's just unimaginable that this firm would hire a man who had a drug problem, publicly documented drug problem, absolutely knew nothing about energy, the Ukraine or international finance for that matter.

TRUMP: I kick that a maybe.

DOBBS: Yeah, well --

TRUMP: Minor details.

DOBBS: Well, these issues. And the Chinese had no problem either, 1.5 billion dollars. He's going to be at least in part the steward for $1.5 billion. It's not an inconsiderable amount of money even for the Chinese. And that, I would guess a good faith in the vice president.

TRUMP: We knew the biggest investors in the world, they go over to China, these are the guys who run the biggest companies in the United States, the biggest investment firms. They go over to China and they can't get three cents out of China.

I mean they can't get any money out of China, and then all of a sudden you have this young guy, who goes there, you know flies aboard in Air Force two, goes to China, comes back, and all of a sudden has a billion five in his pocket. I mean, Lou, it's insane. It's insane.

And this whole witch hunt, it's another witch hunt that they're doing right now. They know they can't beat my father. The corruption is being seen for the 20th time. You've reported on it for the last several years.

DOBBS: From the time he was a candidate, for crying out loud, he's had the FBI and who knows how much other agencies working against him, and how much foreign agencies work

TRUMP: How many more of these scandals do we need to have? Whether it be the fake dossiers, whether it be nonsense Russia investigations, whether it'd be the absolute insane leaks, whether it's Bill Clinton and Loretta Lynch, you know meeting in a private little airport somewhere on the back of a plane.

DOBBS: Loretta Lynch? Did you say Loretta Lynch? We've got most of people don't even know who she is now because she hasn't been considered for investigation by anyone in the Justice Department.

TRUMP: How about Kavanaugh and how about trying to destroy his life? How about all the other lives that they've ruined in the process? And you know what, my father is out there fighting like hell to turn around the country and he's done an unbelievable job.

He's succeeded in every single metric. We are the talk of the entire world and I know that because I quite frankly travel the world and I hear from people. We are doing everything right. He's doing everything right. We have the best markets, we have the best jobs, we have the manufacturing is coming back.

We're winning again on every front, and you know what? The Democrats know it and they want to distract from that, they want to distract from what he's doing and his message, and the patriotism that he's brought back to this country and the winning that he's doing now because they know they can't win.

Biden is not going to win. The guy is a crook, right>? Warren is not going to win. This is somebody who goes out and lies about her native American ancestry. She's not going to win, right.

So, what do they have to do? They have to make up another nonsense diatribe and here we go again. I feel like it's a merry-go-round, I really do.

DOBBS: I wish it were as amusing as a merry-go-round because frankly, this effort to overthrow the president of this congressional -- this constitutional republic.

I mean it's stunning stuff on one hand and as you say on the other it's become old stuff because it has been going on for three years against your father and against this country. And there is a rationalization.

I think it's a psychotic rationalization that broaden our body politic that because the left opposes your father who is an anti-establishment populist president whose appeal crosses both parties, supports the working men and women who is part of the middle class, supports the middle class where their American dream resides instead of the corporatist class. You know, he's fair game and he is not, and neither is this country.

TRUMP: You know what, he threatens their very existence and they know that. And they know that when he came in, look at the movement. Go to these rallies, I've been to so many of them. Go to these rallies where you have 30,000, 40,000, 50,000 people, they're holding American flags, they're cheering USA, USA, USA.

They don't have that on the other side. You know, they are political class. But how many years has Biden been a politician? Over 50, if you include -- I mean he's been a politician Lou, substantially longer than I've been alive, think about that, right? Yet Biden will blame the problems of the country on my father.

DOBBS: Yeah.

TRUMP: Yeah.

DOBBS: It's an incredible thing.

DOBBS: Well, the American people. This is a great thing. The American people are watching all of this. And they're not half as done as the Democrats, the Radical Dems believe them to be.

Or they wouldn't pull such a nonsensical implausible plot as this impeachment inquiry against your father. This is blowing up so quickly. I mean it's exploding right now in the faces of --

TRUMP: There are fundraising numbers show that. Our fundraising number showed that we raised $15 million dollars --

DOBBS: You're such a business guy, it all comes you know what out of money.

TRUMP: It's a great way to show support.

DOBBS: You bet it is.

TRUMP: When people are going online donating 10 bucks and 12 bucks and you raise $15 million in 72 hours including 50,000 people who have never donated to a political party before? It shows where American stands.

People are sick and tired of this nonsense, they're sick and tired of games, they're sick and tired of career politicians and we're going to beat them again.

DOBBS: And still, all of us are still thrilled to win. Eric Trump, thanks.

TRUMP: Good to see you.

DOBBS: Great to see you. Come back soon.

TRUMP: I will.

DOBBS: Up next, here are the 2020 candidate that Facebook's Mark Zuckerberg sees as an existential threat. And the intelligence community's watch dog questioning back on his, well the criticized handling of the so- called whistleblower complaint. It is a construction of language the likes of which you will wish you had never heard but it's coming up next as Victor Davis Hanson, he's with us tonight. Stay with us. we'll be right back.

DOBBS: Facebook's Founder, CEO, Purchaser, Mark Zuckerberg captured in leaked audio blasting presidential candidate Elizabeth Warren and her plans to break up big tech.

MARK ZUCKERBERG, FACEBOOK CEO: Elizabeth Warren thinks that the right answer is to break up the companies. I mean you know, if she gets elected president, then I would bet it that we will have a legal challenge and I would bet that we will win the legal challenge.

Does that still suck for us? Yeah, I mean I don't want to have a major lawsuit against our own government. But look, at the end of the day, if someone's going to try to threaten something that existential, you go to the mat and you fight.

DOBBS: And joining us tonight to take up all of this and much more, former Regan White House, Political Director, Fox Business Political Analyst, Leading Republican Strategies, Ed Rollins.

ED ROLLINS, GREAT AMERICA PAC CHAIRMAN: Thank you.

DOBBS: Ed, good to have you here.

ROLLINS: Nice to be with you, thank you.

DOBBS: Well, let's start with this president was campaigning against big tech before Elizabeth Warren had -- I was going to say left the reservation. The fact of the matter is that's one of his policies. His concerns and his trouble perspective.

ROLLINS: It should be. And at the end of the day, you think Zuckerberg was going endorse Trump the way he was talking about the opposition.

The reality is you need to have some kind of regulatory control in some of these entities that basically out of control. You got all of this information of people out there --

DOBBS: So, you're agreeing with Elizabeth Warren?

ROLLINS: No, I'm agreeing with Donald Trump, what he said originally.

DOBBS: Okay, all right.

ROLLINS: Basically, you know, I think you need to look at it hard and fast.

Lou: Well hard and fast is what I would call --

(LAUGHTER)

-- a hard, fast, and peculiar at the very best. This impeachment inquiry as the Democrats like to call it. This thing is bizarre. There's first no crime as we documented here last night.

ROLLINS: Right.

DOBBS: There is this complaint is riddled with mistakes and errors and concerted efforts it appears with a law firm and a couple congressional committees. And then the coverups, remember the discussion immediately of the coverup.

The coverup just happens to be the routine top-secret code secure files that are presidential conversations are kept in. I mean this is a laughable, just disaster for the Radical Dems as thing that they concocted.

ROLLINS: And you have to understand, the CIA works for the president.

DOBBS: Don't tell me, tell them.

ROLLINS: Their purpose is to gather information from other countries on things for --

DOBBS: They have to go abroad.

ROLLINS: -- the president. Supposed to be abroad not supposed to be here.

DOBBS: Not 1600 Pennsylvania.

ROLLINS: They're not the FBI. They're not -- and the idea that in FBI --

DOBBS: The FBI wanted to wear wires in the White House. I mean what a bunch. You can't make these people up.

ROLLINS: I mean, I've been around a long time and you know first when I worked from the days of J.J. Hoover. He was a minor league player compared to these guys. And we have to be prepared for the big, big fight and I think the Democrats are going to get bloodied and bruised.

And unfortunately, the president has to be very prepared to fight and he will fight.

DOBBS: Well, I don't think there's any trouble about this president fighting.

ROLLINS: No, no.

DOBBS: The real issue here is why in the hell does he have to fight? Because talking with Stephen Miller earlier, this is the deep state. This is the Radical Dems, the left in this country and their compatriots and the leftist national media.

If there were an honest media in this country instead of this closed feedback loop, you know, amongst the Dems, the left, and the leftist media, we wouldn't have this.

ROLLINS: Well, the great indictment against Trump is he's doing what he said he would do. He was unconventional candidate, he's got an unconventional president.

DOBBS: Thank God.

ROLLINS: And he's a very effective president and they're very unhappy about that.

DOBBS: And now, they're trying to -- it seems very clear the Radical Dems are pushing along with the establishment at the White House, wanting to talk you know, maybe we can talk business on trade, we can talk business on tariffs, we can talk business on gun control, we can talk business and you name it.

ROLLINS: Well, the only business the country is going to talk about the next couple months here is going to be their efforts to try to impeach him and they'll be unsuccessful.

DOBBS: Ed Rollins, always good to see you.

ROLLINS: My pleasure. Thank you.

DOBBS: How does it end?

ROLLINS: It ends I think, you know it's about 218 votes, I think they've got the votes to impeach him on some obscure thing. But certainly, the Senate is going to be outraged by it and I think the country is outraged by it.

And they have to take all of this money they're raising and go out and start the campaign day one and go out and tell the country what's going on in Washington, D.C.

DOBBS: Yeah, I can't wait to see him back in the campaign trip.

ROLLINS: That's where he needs to be, he's where he's very good at.

DOBBS: Yeah, thanks so much, appreciate it.

ROLLINS: Pleasure.

DOBBS: Up next, we take up the dramatic escalation of violence in Hong Kong. And what in the world is going on in Beijing. To find out, Dr. Michael Pillsbury joins us. Stay with us, we'll be right back with that and more.

DOBBS: China today unveiled new military weapons including an intercontinental ballistic missile, the DF41 missile flaunted as the most powerful missile on this planet at the 70th anniversary of the Communist Party parade in Beijing.

The missile we're told can carry 10 nuclear war heads theoretically ahs the capability hit the United States within a half hour. Well, Hong King demonstrations today turning extremely violent.

Demonstrators they are taking to the city center more than a 100,000 people marching through the main streets clashing with police, chanting anti-China slogans.

The clashes between the protestors and police escalated and an 18-year-old activist was shot squarely in the chest with a live round by one of the officers. The protester is said to be in critical condition tonight.

Well, joining us now, Dr. Michael Pillsbury, he's director of the center for Chinese strategy at the Hudson Institute. He just returned from Hong Kong and Beijing.

And Mike, it's great to have you with us. This is troubling development how violent and persistent these demonstrations have become.

DR. MICHAEL PILLSBURY, HUDSON CHINESE STRATEGY DIRECTOR: I think it's all part of the rise of Chinese nationalism combined with Chinese power. I mean somebody obviously authorized this police officer to use deadly force.

And the showing of these new weapons systems, besides the missiles they also showed off two robot submarines and they've got a stealth drone that looks a lot like our stealth drone.

They weren't supposed to have this kind of equipment, Lou, for another 10 years according to some experts.

DOBBS: Yeah, I can't imagine them having left it in a file somewhere as they perused all of our intellectual property and technology, and so I'm not in a least surprise in what they have.

PILLSBURY: Well, their weapons look a lot like our weapons.

DOBBS: And their aircraft, for crying out loud. I mean and it's astonishing. I want to turn to the discussion that we've seen the administration pull back.

Peter Navarro talking about, basically saying just basically we were just kidding about keeping China from our markets, the suggestion, there would be a delisting of Chinese companies, oh no, they can have access to everything. Your reaction to that?

(LAUGHTER)

PILLSBURY: Well, every president I worked for wants to maintain secrecy of his policy options until he announces them. So, I understand what Peter Navarro is saying, he's saying he doesn't want to make any comment.

And the White House statement you're referring to, they said at this time, sort of at the very end of the comment about how we're not thinking about escalation and then it was at this time.

So, obviously the question arises for those of us outside the White House, when would be the right time? And my suggestion is if this delegation coming October 10th or 11th. If it has nothing to do in an offer and the talk showed an impasse, then it's time for escalation.

And there's some pretty good ideas, I and others have in mind, including you, Lou.

DOBBS: Well, one of those -- thanks for including me on that lustrous --

PILLSBURY: I'm presuming.

DOBBS: But I'm very concerned right now that we're looking at a country as it talks about a people that won't be stopped, a nation that won't be stopped.

PILLSBURY: I noticed that, yeah.

DOBBS: That is a bellicosity that it seems to me at least as an observer something new for the Chinese because that's an adamant statement of imperial nationalism if I've ever heard one.

PILLSBURY: I think you're right to single out that phrase in President Xi Jinping's speech yesterday. I was struck by it, too. It's more than feisty. It's almost arrogant. In my own meetings in Beijing, I must say there's a new tone of confidence or even arrogance in references to America as yesterday's power.

So, it's the end of a batch (ph) as the way they put it. Yesterday's hegemon. It's kind of insulting to us, actually.

(LAUGHTER)

DOBBS: Right. Well, the point is to make sure that it's incorrect. And when you've got Wall Street flying over on command from Xi, and the communist party to attend at the feet of the great Xi, you know, it gets to be a little troubling.

And when you've got companies continuing to go ahead with forced transfer of rare and extraordinarily valuable intellectual property when we continue to permit the theft of hundreds of billions of dollars of technology.

I'm scratching my head as to you know whether or not that is such an overwrought claim on the part of the President Xi about China vis-a-vis the United States.

(LAUGHTER)

PILLSBURY: No, no. Have some faith in America, Lou.

DOBBS: I got faith in America.

(LAUGHTER)

I got faith in America. What I don't faith in --

PILLSBURY: What this Wall Street people are worried about is the escalation options. They know one of the options and they hate it. That is no more waivers for Chinese companies that have accounting problems and what they've gotten away with is claiming that the results of accounting are secret.

DOBBS: Yeah.

PILLSBURY: So, they won't give them to us and SCC has gone along with that, with the waiver. That can be changed in one second. There're several other escalation options.

DOBBS: What about and I'm aware of outside advisors and some inside advisors who have suggested to the president that there be a cutoff to our capital markets for the Chinese and that that, you know, whether in that vindication in ending the capital flows to China that would just about amount to half there economy I have it on good council. Your thoughts?

(LAUGHTER)

PILLSBURY: That's for me. That's only one range of options affecting the capital markets and their access. Another one is private equity. There're actually enormous amounts of the private equity in China from U.S. Investment Banks.

That's not really been examined before. The third area is the so-called entity that Huawei and general nuclear and others are already on. The threshold for being on that list is not very clear, so at the discretion of the president he can add more important Chinese companies, the ones, Lou, they call the National Champions adding them to that list.

The combination of these options and there's plenty more, would inflict a lot of pain on China. I wish time had to be done --

DOBBS: And this doing to have the pain?

PILLSBURY: Well no, October the 12th, I think?

DOBBS: All right, Michael Pillsbury, always good to talk with you. Thanks so much.

PILLSBURRY: Thanks, Lou.

DOBBS: Appreciate it. Up next, Los Angeles hoping more money will solve a crisis. It's homeless crisis, a crisis of their hone making. We'll have that and more, Victory Davis Hanson joins me right after this.

DOBBS: There is nothing sanctuary in the sanctuary state for the homeless. There is a homeless crisis in Los Angeles that's now hit the breaking point apparently.

City officials there are trying to pressure Governor Newsom to declare a state of emergency in their state and city. City officials hoping to declare that state of emergency and divert more funds to combat homelessness.

Since last year, the homeless population in Los Angeles County has risen 12 percent. The total population nearly 60,000 people.

Well, joining us tonight is Victor Davis Hanson, a senior fellow, and military history at the Hoover Institution, professor at Emeritus sub- classics. A California State University, Fresno.

He is the author and best-selling author and national review contributor. Man, by the time I get through the --

(LAUGHTER)

-- honoraria here, it's stunning stuff and it's good to see you, my friend.

VICTOR DAVIS HANSON, HOOVER INSTITUTE SENIOR FELLOW: Good to see you, Lou.

DOBBS: Let's start with the absurdity of Los Angeles having to declare a crisis because its policies have created so much homelessness.

HANSON: Yeah, I think California's reaching the logical limitation of this radical progressive thought. We're starting to see a medieval culture where people are infected with hepatitis B, e-coli, and even typhus.

And they go to the bathroom on the sidewalk, they shoot drugs and the whole idea is predicated that no one has the intellectual answer or the moral courage to say that's wrong and we're going to address it.

And partly Lou, it's because the Hollywood elite, the people who live down in Malibu or in San Francisco, the Gavin Newsoms, the Feinstein, and Presidio Heights, Pacific Heights, they're never subject to the ramifications of their own utopia and ideology and they're the architects of this culture.

DOBBS: Yeah, they deserve that consequences, don't they?

HANSON: Yes, they --

DOBBS: Victor, let me -- let's go to -- I'm sorry, go ahead, very quickly.

HANSON: It just doesn't fall on them because they have the money and the influence, the gated community, the private security patrol. And that's symptomatic of California.

DOBBS: Yeah, and a few other places, too, D.C. does come to mind.

HANSON: Yes.

DOBBS: Let's turn to the Radical Dems and this absurd quest to carry out an impeachment inquiry against this president with a clause that has no crime within point of fact a complaint that is authored by a CIA officer with third-person -- third-hand information.

And an allegation of a cover-up that happens to be the routine practice of secreting conversations between the president of the United States and foreign leaders. What make you of this?

HANSON: Well, I think what happen is that Nancy Pelosi was under pressure from her base and people in Congress that they warned her that the election is going to come up in 13 months and Donald Trump is going to win.

And some of them have explicitly said if we don't impeach him, we have eight years of him so before she got whistleblower's complaint and had read it, she went ahead with the so-called inquiry.

And what these land mines are starting to blow up in her face and what are the land mines? she doesn't know who the whistleblower is? Has the whistleblower contacted Adam Schiff's staff?

These are questions here she will be asked. Do they have a legal team draw up this? Though can't impeach a president on hearsay evidence and anonymous sources, just doesn't work. So, I think they're trying to get a --

DOBBS: That's what they're trying to do. Very quickly --

HANSON: They're trying to get the Kavanaugh circus. I think they feel if that they get an inquiry, they'll have an I am Sparticus moment, they'll have a Susan and Ford witness and nobody can control it.

They'll bring in everybody. They don't understand that this has happened for three years and people are getting tired of it. And meanwhile, we have all of these things that Pelosi can't control.

There's the Uber investigation, the Horowitz, the Durham investigation. We've got the debates, we've got nine crazy debates still to go. And there's going to be a lot of atmospherics that you can't anticipate.

She can't control the news cycle when she let the genie out of the bottle and nobody knows what's going to happen. But I don't think it's going to be good for her in a long run. They've taken out their premiere candidate, Joe Biden.

DOBBS: Well, Victor Davis Hanson, we're delighted to have our premiere guest with us again tonight. Come back soon.

HANSON: Thank you.

DOBBS: Stay with us. We'll be right back with more.

DOBBS: The desperate Radical Dems coup attempt against the president again over a highly questionable whistleblower claim, senior policy advisor for the president, Stephen Miller with a warning about what's at stake.

MILLER: But what you have with this current non-scandal, non-controversy made-up phoney story from this fake whistleblower about Ukraine, what you have is somebody inside the government along with their allies trying to overthrow a democratically elected president so they can get their policies that they want put in place. That's what's at stake for every American.

DOBBS: And that's it for us tonight. Tomorrow night, the RNC's Donna McDaniel joins us. We hope you will as well. Thanks for joining us here tonight. Good night from New York.

LOU DOBBS, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good evening, everybody. Many of the Radical Dems and the left wing national media are in harmony on almost all national issues. And there's no dissidents at all with the views of corporate America and Wall Street.

And they passionately oppose with scant exceptions. President Trump tough stands on China's expansionary foreign policy and its mercantile trade policies, and outright theft of American technology and intellectual property. No matter it seems the cost to the United States and American workers.

(START VIDEO CLIP)

BILL MAHER, TV HOST AND POLITICAL COMMENTATOR: I have been saying for about two years that I hope we have a recession. A recession would be very worth getting rid of Donald Trump.

JOHN AVLON, CNN ANCHOR: There are plenty of signs of a possible recession.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: If we did face a recession, it would be normal, and it would be okay.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: There's been sort of a wing in the administration that has kind of push to be tough on China. But even though those people I'm hearing are starting to realize the importance of getting a deal done with China if they all want to have a job four years from now.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

DOBBS: President Trump today reminded all Americans of Beijing's decades of predatory trade practices China's theft of American intellectual property and technology, and the massive trade surpluses with United States over decades. It all amounts to trillions of dollars.

(START VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: China has been ripping this country off for 25 years, or longer than that. And it's about time, whether good for our country or bad for our country short-term. Long-term, it's imperative that somebody does this.

I don't know how to value intellectual property theft but they have experts let's say it's at least $300 billion a year where they steal it, somebody had to do something with China.

Obama should have done it, Bush should have done it, Clinton should have done it, they all should have done it. Nobody did it, I'm doing it. So what do you say, my trade deals are causing -- my trade deals aren't causing a problem.

This is something that had to be done, the only differences I'm doing it.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

DOBBS: Is trade deals are actually the solution? Tonight we ask why everyone of President Trump's public policy initiatives and policies whether it be challenging China's aggression or its trade deficits or the President's efforts to secure our border with Mexico and to assure the safety of Americans.

Why is that anathema to the radical Dems, the rinos, the national left wing media, corporate America, and Wall Street? Why is it the elites hate our president and his America first agenda?

It all begs the question, who would these globalist elites put first if not America? We'll try to get to the answer to that question here tonight. And is the president support amongst African-Americans and Hispanics, the reason that the radical left has now ginned up its baseless vicious attacks using race as a weapon.

And has the once reliable coalition of the left, finally had its feel of the Democratic Party's insult. The country two largest minority groups appear to be tiring of the left, treating them like fools, as if they will continue to put up with senseless slurs against this president with no evidence, just hate while the president produces for all Americans, keeping his promise to all Americans.

The president's policies delivering record employment levels for African- Americans last month, near record levels of unemployment at six percent.

Hispanics also enjoying near record levels of unemployment at 4.5 percent. We'll show you the latest polling on the president support among those groups and likely the reason that Democrats are in a new higher stage of desperation.

We begin tonight with breaking news. NRA Chief Executive Wayne LaPierre says President Trump today assured him that universal background checks are off the table. The NRA tweeted the development, President Trump had sent clear signals on the issue earlier in the day.

President Trump saying that he and the Republican Party are very strong on the second amendment.

(START VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: The Democrats would I believe, I think they'd give up the second amendment. And the people that a lot of the people that put me where I am, are strong believers in the second amendment, and I am also, and we have to be very careful about that.

You know, they call it the slippery slope, and all of a sudden everything gets taken away, we're not going to let that happen.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

DOBBS: And joining us tonight, former congressman, former chairman of the house oversight committee, Jason Chaffetz, also best-selling author and Fox Business contributor. urn:contentItem:5WKM-K301-JC65-53M8-00000-00Dems pan 'Zuck buck,' want Facebook to rein in currency plan2019-07-17T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:39:50ZLexisNexisBUSINESS NEWSDems pan 'Zuck buck,' want Facebook to rein in currency planBy MARCY GORDONAP Business WriterWASHINGTON

WASHINGTON (AP) - Facebook endured a second day of criticism from Congress over its plan to create a digital currency as senior House Democrats asked Facebook to scale back the project and threatened legislation that would block big tech companies from getting into banking.

Facebook's massive market power and its record of scandals, fines and privacy breaches were on trial at a hearing Wednesday of the House Financial Services Committee. Lawmakers from both parties insisted they cannot trust the social network giant.

"I think you're pretty low on the trust spectrum right now, and understandably," Rep. Vicente Gonzalez, D-Texas, told David Marcus, the Facebook executive leading the project. It was Marcus' second straight day of tough questioning by lawmakers.

Among their concerns is the risk that the new currency, to be called Libra, could be used for illicit activity such as money laundering or drug trafficking. Lawmakers also worry that the massive reserve created with money used to buy Libra could supplant the Federal Reserve and destabilize the financial system, and that consumers could be hurt by Libra losses.

The committee's leader, Rep. Maxine Waters, D-Calif., has asked Facebook to suspend its plan for the new currency until regulators and lawmakers have a chance to fully review it. She renewed that demand to Marcus.

Rep. Carolyn Maloney, D-N.Y., asked that Facebook commit to starting with a pilot project with no more than a million users, overseen by the Federal Reserve.

If Facebook cannot meet that request, Maloney said, "then Congress should seriously consider stopping this project from moving forward."

Waters held out the prospect of legislation that would prohibit big tech companies such as Facebook, Google, Amazon and Apple from becoming chartered or licensed as U.S. financial institutions, and thus able to offer banking services, and specifically from establishing a digital currency.

Facebook, marshaling its more than 2 billion users around the world, "is apparently trying to create a new global financial system that will compete with the U.S. dollar," Waters said.

The congressional criticism thickened the cloud over Facebook's plan, coming after negative statements and expressions of concern from the two most powerful financial regulators , Fed Chairman Jerome Powell and Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin, as well as from President Donald Trump himself.

In a rare endorsement of Trump's views, committee Democrats projected his negative tweets last week about cryptocurrencies and Libra on a giant electronic screen in the hearing room. Trump said Libra "will have little standing or dependability."

As he did at Tuesday's hearing by the Senate Banking, Housing and Urban Affairs Committee, Marcus repeatedly took pains to assure lawmakers that Facebook would not launch the currency project until it had received all the necessary approvals from regulators and secured safeguards to protect the privacy of users' data. He said Facebook will not control Libra because Facebook will be only one of about 100 companies and nonprofits in an association that will manage the currency.

Marcus said the plan would open low-cost online commerce to millions of people around the world who lack access to bank accounts and would make it cheaper to send money across borders.

He did not agree to a suspension of the plan or a pilot project.

"We will take the time to get this right," Marcus said.

He said Facebook isn't looking to base the Libra project in Switzerland in order to evade oversight, but because that country is recognized as an international financial center.

Acknowledging lawmakers' concerns over Facebook's record on data privacy , Marcus said, "I think trust is essential and it's clear we've made mistakes. We're owning these mistakes."

The committee's senior Republican, Rep. Patrick McHenry of North Carolina, said skepticism over the project is justified but the effort should not be prohibited outright. A thorough review is needed, "instead of a knee-jerk reaction of banning something before it begins," McHenry said.

Rep. Tom Emmer, R-Minn., said the legislation Waters is proposing to ban big tech companies from banking "has no constitutional basis."

Marcus' assurance that Facebook won't control Libra failed to convince Rep. Brad Sherman, D-Calif., who focused on Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg.

"This is the Zuck buck," Sherman insisted. "This is a godsend to drug dealers" and other criminals. "Zuckerberg has billions but he doesn't have the authority to print more. ... This is an attempt to transfer enormous power from America to Facebook and its allies."

The planned digital currency is to be a blend of multiple currencies, which means the exchange rate will fluctuate.

urn:contentItem:5WKX-MNT1-JCH9-G162-00000-00Dems pan 'Zuck buck,' want Facebook to rein in currency plan2019-07-18T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:39:50ZLexisNexisDems pan 'Zuck buck,' want Facebook to rein in currency plan

Facebook endured a second day of criticism from Congress over its plan to create a digital currency as senior House Democrats asked Facebook to scale back the project and threatened legislation that would block big tech companies from getting into banking.

Facebook's massive market power and its record of scandals, fines and privacy breaches were on trial at a hearing Wednesday of the House Financial Services Committee. Lawmakers from both parties insisted they cannot trust the social network giant.

"I think you're pretty low on the trust spectrum right now, and understandably," Rep. Vicente Gonzalez, D-Texas, told David Marcus, the Facebook executive leading the project. It was Marcus' second straight day of tough questioning by lawmakers.

Among their concerns is the risk that the new currency, to be called Libra, could be used for illicit activity such as money laundering or drug trafficking. Lawmakers also worry that the massive reserve created with money used to buy Libra could supplant the Federal Reserve and destabilize the financial system, and that consumers could be hurt by Libra losses.

The committee's leader, Rep. Maxine Waters, D-Calif., has asked Facebook to suspend its plan for the new currency until regulators and lawmakers have a chance to fully review it. She renewed that demand to Marcus.

Rep. Carolyn Maloney, D-N.Y., asked that Facebook commit to starting with a pilot project with no more than a million users, overseen by the Federal Reserve.

If Facebook cannot meet that request, Maloney said, "then Congress should seriously consider stopping this project from moving forward."

Waters held out the prospect of legislation that would prohibit big tech companies such as Facebook, Google, Amazon and Apple from becoming chartered or licensed as U.S. financial institutions, and thus able to offer banking services, and specifically from establishing a digital currency.

Facebook, marshaling its more than 2 billion users around the world, "is apparently trying to create a new global financial system that will compete with the U.S. dollar," Waters said.

The congressional criticism thickened the cloud over Facebook's plan, coming after negative statements and expressions of concern from the two most powerful financial regulators , Fed Chairman Jerome Powell and Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin, as well as from President Donald Trump himself.

In a rare endorsement of Trump's views, committee Democrats projected his negative tweets last week about cryptocurrencies and Libra on a giant electronic screen in the hearing room. Trump said Libra "will have little standing or dependability."

As he did at Tuesday's hearing by the Senate Banking, Housing and Urban Affairs Committee, Marcus repeatedly took pains to assure lawmakers that Facebook would not launch the currency project until it had received all the necessary approvals from regulators and secured safeguards to protect the privacy of users' data. He said Facebook will not control Libra because Facebook will be only one of about 100 companies and nonprofits in an association that will manage the currency.

Marcus said the plan would open low-cost online commerce to millions of people around the world who lack access to bank accounts and would make it cheaper to send money across borders.

He did not agree to a suspension of the plan or a pilot project.

"We will take the time to get this right," Marcus said.

He said Facebook isn't looking to base the Libra project in Switzerland in order to evade oversight, but because that country is recognized as an international financial center.

Acknowledging lawmakers' concerns over Facebook's record on data privacy , Marcus said, "I think trust is essential and it's clear we've made mistakes. We're owning these mistakes."

The committee's senior Republican, Rep. Patrick McHenry of North Carolina, said skepticism over the project is justified but the effort should not be prohibited outright. A thorough review is needed, "instead of a knee-jerk reaction of banning something before it begins," McHenry said.

Rep. Tom Emmer, R-Minn., said the legislation Waters is proposing to ban big tech companies from banking "has no constitutional basis."

Marcus' assurance that Facebook won't control Libra failed to convince Rep. Brad Sherman, D-Calif., who focused on Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg.

"This is the Zuck buck," Sherman insisted. "This is a godsend to drug dealers" and other criminals. "Zuckerberg has billions but he doesn't have the authority to print more. This is an attempt to transfer enormous power from America to Facebook and its allies."

The planned digital currency is to be a blend of multiple currencies, which means the exchange rate will fluctuate.

urn:contentItem:5WKY-6671-DXVP-V4SV-00000-00Dems pan 'Zuck buck,' want Facebook to rein in currency plan2019-07-18T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:39:49ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 3Dems pan 'Zuck buck,' want Facebook to rein in currency planMARCY GORDON AP Business Writer

Facebook endured a second day of criticism from Congress over its plan to create a digital currency as senior House Democrats asked Facebook to scale back the project and threatened legislation that would block big tech companies from getting into banking.

Facebook's massive market power and its record of scandals, fines and privacy breaches were on trial at a hearing Wednesday of the House Financial Services Committee. Lawmakers from both parties insisted they cannot trust the social network giant.

"I think you're pretty low on the trust spectrum right now, and understandably," Rep. Vicente Gonzalez, D-Texas, told David Marcus, the Facebook executive leading the project. It was Marcus' second straight day of tough questioning by lawmakers.

Among their concerns is the risk that the new currency, to be called Libra, could be used for illicit activity such as money laundering or drug trafficking. Lawmakers also worry that the massive reserve created with money used to buy Libra could supplant the Federal Reserve and destabilize the financial system, and that consumers could be hurt by Libra losses.

The committee's leader, Rep. Maxine Waters, D-Calif., has asked Facebook to suspend its plan for the new currency until regulators and lawmakers have a chance to fully review it. She renewed that demand to Marcus.

Rep. Carolyn Maloney, D-N.Y., asked that Facebook commit to starting with a pilot project with no more than a million users, overseen by the Federal Reserve.

If Facebook cannot meet that request, Maloney said, "then Congress should seriously consider stopping this project from moving forward."

Waters held out the prospect of legislation that would prohibit big tech companies such as Facebook, Google, Amazon and Apple from becoming chartered or licensed as U.S. financial institutions, and thus able to offer banking services, and specifically from establishing a digital currency.

Facebook, marshaling its more than 2 billion users around the world, "is apparently trying to create a new global financial system that will compete with the U.S. dollar," Waters said.

The congressional criticism thickened the cloud over Facebook's plan, coming after negative statements and expressions of concern from the two most powerful financial regulators , Fed Chairman Jerome Powell and Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin, as well as from President Donald Trump himself.

In a rare endorsement of Trump's views, committee Democrats projected his negative tweets last week about cryptocurrencies and Libra on a giant electronic screen in the hearing room. Trump said Libra "will have little standing or dependability."

As he did at Tuesday's hearing by the Senate Banking, Housing and Urban Affairs Committee, Marcus repeatedly took pains to assure lawmakers that Facebook would not launch the currency project until it had received all the necessary approvals from regulators and secured safeguards to protect the privacy of users' data. He said Facebook will not control Libra because Facebook will be only one of about 100 companies and nonprofits in an association that will manage the currency.

Marcus said the plan would open low-cost online commerce to millions of people around the world who lack access to bank accounts and would make it cheaper to send money across borders.

He did not agree to a suspension of the plan or a pilot project.

"We will take the time to get this right," Marcus said.

He said Facebook isn't looking to base the Libra project in Switzerland in order to evade oversight, but because that country is recognized as an international financial center.

Acknowledging lawmakers' concerns over Facebook's record on data privacy , Marcus said, "I think trust is essential and it's clear we've made mistakes. We're owning these mistakes."

The committee's senior Republican, Rep. Patrick McHenry of North Carolina, said skepticism over the project is justified but the effort should not be prohibited outright. A thorough review is needed, "instead of a knee-jerk reaction of banning something before it begins," McHenry said.

Rep. Tom Emmer, R-Minn., said the legislation Waters is proposing to ban big tech companies from banking "has no constitutional basis."

Marcus' assurance that Facebook won't control Libra failed to convince Rep. Brad Sherman, D-Calif., who focused on Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg.

"This is the Zuck buck," Sherman insisted. "This is a godsend to drug dealers" and other criminals. "Zuckerberg has billions but he doesn't have the authority to print more. ... This is an attempt to transfer enormous power from America to Facebook and its allies."

The planned digital currency is to be a blend of multiple currencies, which means the exchange rate will fluctuate.

Rep. Carolyn Maloney, D-N.Y., asked that Facebook commit to starting with a pilot project with no more than a million users, overseen by the Federal Reserve.

If Facebook cannot meet that request, Maloney said, "then Congress should seriously consider stopping this project from moving forward."

Waters held out the prospect of legislation that would prohibit big tech companies such as Facebook, Google, Amazon and Apple from becoming chartered or licensed as U.S. financial institutions, and thus able to offer banking services, and specifically from establishing a digital currency.

Facebook, marshalling its more than 2 billion users around the world, "is apparently trying to create a new global financial system that will compete with the U.S. dollar," Waters said.

The congressional criticism thickened the cloud over Facebook's plan, coming after negative statements and expressions of concern from the two most powerful financial regulators , Fed Chairman Jerome Powell and Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin, as well as from President Donald Trump himself.

In a rare endorsement of Trump's views, committee Democrats projected his negative tweets last week about cryptocurrencies and Libra on a giant electronic screen in the hearing room. Trump said Libra "will have little standing or dependability."

As he did at Tuesday's hearing by the Senate Banking, Housing and Urban Affairs Committee, Marcus repeatedly took pains to assure lawmakers that Facebook would not launch the currency project until it had received all the necessary approvals from regulators and secured safeguards to protect the privacy of users' data. He said Facebook will not control Libra because Facebook will be only one of about 100 companies and nonprofits in an association that will manage the currency.

Marcus said the plan would open low-cost online commerce to millions of people around the world who lack access to bank accounts and would make it cheaper to send money across borders.

He did not agree to a suspension of the plan or a pilot project.

"We will take the time to get this right," Marcus said.

He said Facebook isn't looking to base the Libra project in Switzerland in order to evade oversight, but because that country is recognized as an international financial centre.

Acknowledging lawmakers' concerns over Facebook's record on data privacy , Marcus said, "I think trust is essential and it's clear we've made mistakes. We're owning these mistakes."

The committee's senior Republican, Rep. Patrick McHenry of North Carolina, said skepticism over the project is justified but the effort should not be prohibited outright. A thorough review is needed, "instead of a knee-jerk reaction of banning something before it begins," McHenry said.

Rep. Tom Emmer, R-Minn., said the legislation Waters is proposing to ban big tech companies from banking "has no constitutional basis."

Marcus' assurance that Facebook won't control Libra failed to convince Rep. Brad Sherman, D-Calif., who focused on Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg.

"This is the Zuck buck," Sherman insisted. "This is a godsend to drug dealers" and other criminals. "Zuckerberg has billions but he doesn't have the authority to print more. ... This is an attempt to transfer enormous power from America to Facebook and its allies."

The planned digital currency is to be a blend of multiple currencies, which means the exchange rate will fluctuate.

urn:contentItem:5T2M-96F1-JBG3-62TT-00000-00Demystifying Online Privacy, Through the Story of the Man Who Took On Silicon Valley2018-08-18T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:39:50ZLexisNexisINSIDERDemystifying Online Privacy, Through the Story of the Man Who Took On Silicon ValleyNicholas Confessore

The tech world presents itself as too complicated to understand. But Alastair Mactaggart, a privacy advocate I profiled, cracked it — and so can you.

Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times.

I usually think of myself as a politics reporter, the job I’ve had, on and off, for most of my career. But in the last year or so, I’ve had to add another title, one I never thought I’d have: tech reporter.

In the Trump era, those two topics are increasingly hard to separate. In the last year, I’ve written about the booming business of “bots” and fake accounts on Twitter and   how Russian agents used fake Facebook pages to sow division and shape the 2016 presidential election. I also worked on a Times investigation, in partnership with The Guardian and The Observer of London, into Cambridge Analytica, the British-American political data firm   that improperly exploited the personal Facebook data of tens of millions of American voters. To study political power today, you have to understand technology.

That’s what drew me to the story of Alastair Mactaggart, the central character in this Sunday’s magazine cover story about the war over privacy. In the wake of the Cambridge Analytica scandal, it has become clear that tech companies like Google and Facebook not only collect extraordinary amounts of information about everyone, but sometimes deceive or mislead their own users about what information is being collected and how it is used.

My colleagues and I have reported extensively over the last year on the enormous power wielded by tech companies over politics and commerce and on the ways in which that power can be abused. Our reporting has shed light on how poorly tech companies protect the integrity of their platforms and of the data you hand them for free, with profound consequences.

Yet both Facebook and Google, and the broader tech industry of which they are a part, have escaped any major regulation or seriously punitive government action in the United States. (In Europe, Google was recently hit with a $5 billion fine for antitrust violations.) Even after a cascade of scandals, Washington had done almost nothing. Why?

Mr. Mactaggart, who last year began organizing to pass a California ballot initiative restricting the abuse of personal data, turned out to be an ideal way to answer the question. For one thing, his campaign was happening in real time, and as a political neophyte, he was encountering Silicon Valley’s political machine for the first time, much as most readers would be. Mr. Mactaggart was not an expert on privacy when he started; he was a wealthy real estate developer from Oakland, whose main interaction with people in the tech world was at Bay Area birthday parties and his neighborhood dog run. He more or less fell into a rabbit hole and became a little obsessed. That journey allowed me to turn an arcane and often boring subject into a compelling yarn; his education — as a political campaigner and as a consumer — becomes the reader’s.

That was important for me, too, as a reporter. I often write about complex policy issues, and questions surrounding data collection, advertising and privacy can be challenging to unspool in a compelling, accessible way.

I used to write about campaign finance; that’s a complicated topic, too, and it was easy to lose readers’ attention. But writing about data and privacy is harder. Presidential campaigns lend a certain innate drama to stories about donors and fund-raising. Tech and social media, while in one sense nearer to people’s daily lives, can seem distant and abstract. For those who have no background in programming or data science, the industry they animate can seem impenetrable.

This is no accident. One reason Big Tech faces so little resistance from policymakers is that Silicon Valley’s business seems so daunting. I find that Big Tech’s lobbyists and “thought leaders” — and some journalists — implicitly and sometimes explicitly promote the idea that policymakers are too dumb, slow or unsophisticated to understand how it all works, let alone regulate something like data collection practices. This notion also helps insulate the industry from accountability.

The story of how Mr. Mactaggart forced California lawmakers to pass a landmark consumer privacy law is, in part, a story of the power of this idea — and also of its flimsiness. The law he helped pass is not a panacea, and won’t solve every problem raised by the encroaching powers of Big Tech. Some critics believe the law doesn’t go far enough. (And many in the industry believe it goes way too far.) But the fact of it — the political proof of concept — has already stirred intense debate and pressure to produce even more protections for consumers, not only in other states but in Washington.

That matters not only for consumers, but also for readers. Mr. Mactaggart is a smart guy, and he had time and resources most people don’t. But he’s not an expert on politics or technology. If he can figure it out, so can you.
